Apart from his solo work, Injeti has also been actively involved in producing and songwriting for other artists. He has worked with several renowned acts, including Eminem, Aloe Blacc, Estelle, and Dr. Dre. One of his most notable collaborations was with the American rapper, Kendrick Lamar. Injeti produced and co-wrote several tracks on Lamar's critically acclaimed album, "good kid, m.A.A.d city." The album went on to win several awards, including a Grammy for Best Rap Performance. In 2013, Injeti formed the musical project, "Chin Injeti & The Lifers," which featured a collective of Canadian musicians. The group released their debut album, "We Don't Know Yet," which incorporated elements of folk, rock, and soul. The album showcased Injeti's versatility as an artist and earned positive reviews from critics. In 2019, Injeti released his second solo album, "The Revenge of the Analog," which was a tribute to the vintage analog sound of the 70s and 80s. The album featured collaborations with several Canadian musicians and showcased Injeti's continued growth as an artist. In conclusion, Chin Injeti is a versatile and talented artist who has made significant contributions to the music industry. His diverse range of influences and collaborations have earned him critical acclaim and a dedicated fan base. His discography is a testament to his creativity and versatility as an artist.

The Finland Plot, also known as the "Tanner Affair," was a political scandal that took place in Finland during the 1950s. The plot involved accusations that a group of individuals, including the Finnish Prime Minister, Juho Kusti Paasikivi, and his successor, Karl-August Fagerholm, worked with the Soviet Union to maintain their power and influence in the Finnish government. The allegations were first made public by the Finnish Ambassador to Sweden, Max Jakobson, in a series of articles published in the Swedish press in 1954. Jakobson claimed that Paasikivi and Fagerholm had made a secret deal with Soviet officials during the Moscow Conference in 1952, in which they agreed to follow pro-Soviet policies in exchange for Soviet support. The accusations sparked a public outcry in Finland, with many demanding an investigation into the matter. The Finnish Parliament established a commission to investigate the allegations, and over the next few months, the commission heard testimony from a number of witnesses, including Jakobson, Paasikivi, and Fagerholm. In the end, the commission was unable to find any concrete evidence of a plot or conspiracy. However, the accusations had a significant impact on Finnish politics, damaging the reputations of Paasikivi and Fagerholm and contributing to a shift in Finnish foreign policy away from the Soviet Union. Today, the Finland Plot remains a controversial and divisive topic in Finnish politics and history. While some view it as a legitimate concern about Soviet influence in Finnish affairs, others see it as a politically motivated smear campaign against left-leaning politicians. Regardless of one's perspective, the Finland Plot serves as a reminder of the complex and often fraught relationship between Finland and its powerful neighbor to the east.

Michael Hansmeyer is a Swiss architect and computer scientist who is known for his pioneering work in computational design. Born in Geneva in 1976, Hansmeyer was educated in Switzerland and the United States, where he studied architecture and computer science at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich and Cornell University, respectively. Hansmeyer's interest in computational design began in the early 2000s, when he began experimenting with algorithms to generate complex and intricate forms. His early projects included the design of a pavilion for the Swiss National Expo in 2002, which featured a complex pattern of interlocking wooden panels. One of Hansmeyer's most notable projects is his work on the Grotto II series, which consists of a series of 3D-printed architectural columns that are based on algorithmic generation and refinement. Each column is composed of over eight million polygons, and features intricate branching structures that evoke natural forms such as coral reefs and fractal patterns. Hansmeyer's work has been exhibited at numerous international exhibitions, including the Venice Biennale and the Centre Pompidou in Paris. He has also been recognized with a number of awards and honors for his contributions to computational design, including the Swiss Art Award, the Ars Electronica Honorary Mention, and the Architizer A+ Award. In addition to his work as an architect and designer, Hansmeyer is also a leading researcher and educator in the field of computational design. He has taught at a number of institutions, including the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology and the University of Applied Sciences in Zurich, and has published numerous academic articles and papers on the topic of computational design.

MS Cruise Roma is a large passenger and roll-on/roll-off ferry owned by Grimaldi Lines. The vessel was built at the STX Finland shipyard in Turku, Finland in 2010 and launched on September 17th of the same year. The ship is a part of a series of vessels commissioned by Grimaldi Lines and is capable of carrying up to 3,700 passengers and 3,000 cars across the Mediterranean Sea. The Cruise Roma's interior is a modern design that emphasizes comfort and relaxation. The passenger cabins are elegantly appointed. Amenities include a number of restaurants, bars, a disco, shops, a casino, a cinema, and a children's play area. For vehicles on-board, the ship has secure and spacious garages to transport cars, motorhomes, and other types of vehicles. The ship measures 225 meters in length, 30.4 meters in width, and has a gross tonnage of 63,000 tonnes. It has a top speed of 27.5 knots (51 km/h) and can carry up to 230 trailers in its garage. To ensure the safety of the passengers, the ship is equipped with the latest navigation and safety equipment. Cruise Roma operates mainly for Mediterranean routes, connecting the ports of Civitavecchia, Barcelona, and Porto Torres. It can make the crossing between Civitavecchia and Barcelona in approximately 20 hours, making it a popular choice for passengers traveling for business or leisure. The ship's crossing to Porto Torres takes roughly 13 hours. The MS Cruise Roma is considered as one of the most innovative ferries in the world. Its sophisticated design and modern amenities provide passengers with a true sea voyage experience. The ship has earned numerous recognitions throughout the years and is widely regarded as a testament to the technological advancements in the maritime industry.

Cat Person is a term often used to describe someone who loves and is passionate about cats. A Cat Person is someone who enjoys the company of cats and may own multiple cats as pets. They are typically associated with being nurturing, patient, and caring towards cats, and they often take great pride in their feline friends. Being a Cat Person is not limited to a specific gender or age group. People of all ages, genders, and backgrounds can be Cat People. Despite the common stereotype of the "crazy cat lady," there are just as many men who proudly identify as Cat People. Research has shown that owning a cat can have many positive effects on one's physical and mental health. Studies have found that cat owners have lower blood pressure, lower stress levels, and a decreased risk of heart disease. Not to mention, the affectionate nature of cats can provide a sense of comfort and companionship to their owners. The term "cat person" can be traced back to the early 1800s when the first domesticated cats arrived in the United States. The popularity of cats continued to grow throughout the 20th century, with cats being ranked as one of the most popular pets in the world. In recent years, Cat People have gained a strong online presence, with social media platforms like Instagram and Twitter highlighting the joys of being a Cat Person. There are now countless pages and accounts dedicated to celebrating feline companions and sharing photos and videos of cats in all their glory. In conclusion, being a Cat Person is a unique and treasured identity that brings joy and companionship to countless individuals around the world. Whether it's cuddling with their cat or watching funny cat videos online, Cat People have found a special connection with these playful and fascinating creatures.

Pleurotus citrinopileatus, commonly known as the Golden Oyster Mushroom, is a species of edible mushroom that belongs to the family Pleurotaceae. The mushroom is native to the eastern regions of Asia, but it has been successfully cultivated in other parts of the world as well. It is known for its bright yellow or golden caps, delicate texture, and subtle, nutty flavor that makes it a popular ingredient in a wide range of dishes. The Golden Oyster Mushroom has a fan-shaped cap that ranges in size from 3 to 10 cm in diameter when fully mature. The cap is typically golden-yellow in color, while the stalk is white or cream-colored. The flesh of the mushroom is thin, delicate, and tender, and it has a slightly sweet aroma that is reminiscent of almonds or anise. The mushroom is known to be a rich source of nutrients, such as protein, dietary fiber, potassium, phosphorus, and vitamins B and D. It is also said to have antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties that make it beneficial for human health. The Golden Oyster Mushroom is a relatively easy mushroom to grow, and it can be cultivated indoors or outdoors in controlled environments. It grows best in temperatures between 10 and 25 degrees Celsius and requires a substrate that is rich in nutrients. The mushroom is typically grown on a variety of substrates, including straw, sawdust, hardwood logs, and composted manure. In addition to its culinary uses, the Golden Oyster Mushroom is also used for medicinal purposes in traditional Chinese medicine. It is believed to have immune-boosting properties and may be useful in the treatment of certain chronic illnesses. Overall, Pleurotus citrinopileatus is a versatile and delicious mushroom that is enjoyed by many people around the world. Its bright color, delicate texture, and subtle nutty flavor make it a popular ingredient in a wide range of dishes, while its nutritional and medicinal properties make it a valuable addition to a healthy diet.

List of France national rugby union team records The France national rugby union team is one of the oldest and most successful teams in international rugby, having competed in the sport for over a century. Most points in a match The most points scored by a French team in a single match is 77, which they achieved in their 77-0 win over Fiji in 1999. France also scored 73 points against Scotland in 2008. System Development Corporation System Development Corporation (SDC) was a pioneering information technology (IT) firm founded in Santa Monica, California, in 1955. It was one of the first companies to specialize in computer software development and systems integration. History SDC was founded by Douglas Engelbart and a group of engineers who helped design the first digital computer, the UNIVAC, in the 1940s and early 1950s. The company's focus was on developing software applications for business and government clients. In the early years, SDC specialized in developing payroll and accounting systems. By the 1960s, SDC had become a major systems integrator, with contracts from the US Air Force, NASA, and the National Institutes of Health. SDC was also a subcontractor for IBM, helping to develop the operating system for the System/360 mainframe computer. In the 1970s, SDC became a leader in the development of interactive computer systems, including the On-Line System (OLS) and the Computer-Aided Acquisition and Logistic Support (CALS) system for the US military. In the 1980s, SDC shifted its focus to defense-related projects and software development for the government. The company was acquired by Burroughs Corporation (later known as Unisys) in 1986. Legacy SDC was a major player in the development of computer software and systems integration in the early days of the information age. The company's engineers and executives helped shape the IT industry, contributing to advancements in hardware, software, and systems integration. Many SDC alumni went on to create successful IT companies of their own, including Sun Microsystems and Siebel Systems. The legacy of SDC can still be seen in modern-day software development and systems integration. The company's pioneering work paved the way for the development of sophisticated software applications, interactive computer systems, and advanced systems integration techniques used in modern corporate and government IT infrastructures.

The Ajmer Dargah bombing occurred on October 11, 2007, in the Indian city of Ajmer. The Ajmer Dargah is a Sufi shrine that attracts visitors of all faiths. The attack, carried out by two Islamist extremists, left three dead and 15 injured. The explosion took place just after evening prayers at the shrine. The two bombers, Devender Gupta and Sunil Joshi, planted bombs in the courtyard of the shrine. The bombs were placed in two separate bags, and both of them exploded in quick succession. The Ajmer Dargah bombing was one in a series of attacks carried out by Hindu right-wing extremists across India. The attackers sought to create communal tension by targeting sites of religious significance to Muslims. The investigation into the Ajmer blast, initially slow, uncovered a network of Hindu terrorists operating in several states in India. This network had cells in several major cities, with links to extremist organizations in neighboring countries. The Ajmer Dargah bombing was a particularly brutal attack, as the shrine is a symbol of religious tolerance and mutual respect. The shrine's visitors come from all over India and beyond, and the attack was meant to stoke communal tensions and create chaos. However, like many such attacks, it had the opposite effect, bringing people of different faiths together in mourning and solidarity. The two bombers were eventually caught and sentenced to life imprisonment. The Ajmer Dargah bombing remains a black mark on India's secular democracy, but it also stands as a testament to the resilience and spirit of the Indian people to overcome sectarianism and hatred.

Caregiver burden refers to the physical, emotional, and financial stress experienced by individuals who provide care to a loved one who is ill, disabled, or elderly. The burden encompasses a range of tasks, including bathing and grooming, transportation, medication management, cooking, and cleaning. Caregiver burden is particularly common among individuals who care for those with chronic illnesses such as dementia, cancer, and heart disease. The burden of caregiving can be significant, with caregivers often experiencing higher levels of stress, anxiety, and depression than non-caregivers. Caregiver burnout is a common issue, with many caregivers feeling overwhelmed, exhausted, and guilty for not doing enough for their loved ones. In some cases, caregiver burden can also have a detrimental impact on the caregiver's physical health, with studies suggesting that caregivers have a higher risk of developing conditions such as hypertension, depression, and chronic pain. Caregiver burden can also have a significant financial impact, with many caregivers having to give up their jobs or reduce their work hours to provide care. This can lead to financial strain and difficulties with paying bills and affording necessary medical care. There are several strategies that can help reduce caregiver burden, including respite care, counseling, and support groups. Respite care provides temporary relief for caregivers, allowing them to take a break and focus on their own needs. Counseling and support groups can provide caregivers with emotional support and practical advice on coping with the stress of caregiving. Overall, caregiver burden is a significant issue that affects millions of individuals worldwide. By providing caregivers with the support they need, we can help alleviate the burden of caregiving and improve the quality of life for both caregivers and their loved ones.

Mark Johnston is a highly respected horse racing trainer from Scotland who has become known for his talent and success in the racing industry. As the son of a veterinarian, Johnston grew up around horses and developed a passion for the sport at a young age. Johnston began his career in horse racing as a stable lad and then as an amateur jockey. However, he quickly realized that his true passion lay in training horses. In 1987, he acquired his training license and set up his own stables in Middleham, North Yorkshire. Since then, Johnston has become one of the most successful horse racing trainers in the United Kingdom. He has trained over 4,500 winners, making him the second-most successful trainer in British history. His horses have won numerous high-profile races, including the 2,000 Guineas, the Epsom Derby, and the St. Leger Stakes. Johnston is known for his work ethic and attention to detail, which he credits as the keys to his success. He is involved in every aspect of his horses' care, from their diet and training regimen to their breeding and racing schedules. Despite his success, Johnston remains humble and dedicated to improving his craft. He is often seen walking the paddocks during races and attending horse sales to scout out potential future champions. Johnston's contributions to horse racing have not gone unnoticed. He has been awarded numerous honors, including the Order of the British Empire for his services to racing. His legacy as a trainer continues to inspire a new generation of horse racing enthusiasts.

1940 in South Africa 1940 was a significant year in the history of South Africa. The country, which was still under the government of the United Kingdom, was deeply involved in the Second World War, which had started in September 1939. South Africa had declared war on Germany, one of the Axis powers, on September 6, 1939. South African troops were sent to North Africa, where they fought in the desert campaign against the Axis powers. The country also played an important role in the Battle of Madagascar, which took place in May 1942. South African forces, with the support of the Royal Navy and the Royal Air Force, captured the strategic island from the Vichy French. The war had a significant impact on South African society. Thousands of South Africans joined the military and were sent to fight in different parts of the world. The government also introduced measures to control the economy and resources, including rationing of food, goods, and services. The Union Defence Force was also expanded to cope with the increased demand for soldiers. The army was divided into two divisions, the 1st and 2nd South African Infantry Divisions, and the South African Air Force was formed in 1940. The Navy was also expanded, with the creation of the South African Naval Forces in August 1940. The war had a profound effect on race relations in the country. Although the government initially refused to allow black and coloured soldiers to fight in the war, many still volunteered and formed their own segregated units. The Labour Party, which represented mainly coloured and Indian interests, also gained strength during this time and demanded greater political representation for non-whites. In conclusion, 1940 was a significant year in South African history. The country was deeply involved in the Second World War and played an important role in various campaigns. The war had a significant impact on society, and it also helped to reshape the political landscape of the country.

Tony Brown (born on April 11th, 1946) is a music producer, pianist and songwriter, who has produced numerous chart-topping hits in both the country and pop music industries. He has been awarded with four Grammy Awards, has been credited with producing over 100 number 1 singles, and has been inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame. Brown started his musical career playing piano in R&B bands as a teenager. He then moved to Los Angeles, where he found success as a session musician, playing on recordings for artists such as Elvis Presley, Emmylou Harris, and Linda Ronstadt. In 1984, Brown became the head of the A&R department at MCA Nashville, where he worked with a wide range of country artists such as George Strait, Reba McEntire, and Vince Gill. During his time at MCA, Brown produced numerous hit records, including “Ocean Front Property” by George Strait, “Whoever’s In New England” by Reba McEntire, and “When I Call Your Name” by Vince Gill. In 1995, Brown left MCA to become an independent producer. He quickly found success with artists such as Brooks & Dunn, Steve Earle, and Marty Stuart. Brown's production of “The River” by Garth Brooks was certified 6x platinum by the RIAA and remains one of Brooks' most popular songs. In addition to his producing work, Brown has also released his own music. His solo album “Two-Steppin’ Mind” was released in 1996, and he has also released an album with his band, the Tony Brown Band. Through his work as a producer, Tony Brown has had a significant impact on the country music industry. His contributions have been recognized by his induction into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2019, solidifying his place as one of the most successful and respected music producers of all time.

The National Register of Historic Places listings in Minnesota is a collection of sites, buildings, and structures that have been deemed significant to the state's history. This list was first established in 1966 as a part of the National Historic Preservation Act, which provided for the identification, evaluation, and protection of America's historic resources. There are currently over 1,600 sites on the register in Minnesota. The register includes a wide range of sites, from archaeological sites to significant buildings and districts. Some notable sites in Minnesota on the list include the Split Rock Lighthouse, the Foshay Tower, and the James J. Hill House. The register also includes sites significant to Minnesota's Native American history, such as the Jeffers Petroglyphs. The listing process for the register is overseen by the Minnesota State Historic Preservation Office, which evaluates each site based on criteria established by the National Park Service. Sites are evaluated based on their significance to American history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, and culture. Being listed on the register provides a level of recognition and protection for a site, as well as access to certain preservation funds. It also encourages historic preservation by promoting public awareness of these significant sites. In addition to the statewide register, individual counties and municipalities may also establish their own listings of significant historic sites. The Minnesota Historical Society also maintains a list of historic sites and museums throughout the state. Overall, the National Register of Historic Places listings in Minnesota provides a valuable record of the state's rich history and cultural heritage. It serves as a testament to the importance of preserving our nation's past for future generations to learn from and enjoy.

Asensio Nebot is a Spanish scientist known for his research in the field of drug delivery systems and polymer chemistry. Born on December 5, 1975, in Zaragoza, Spain, Nebot has always had a keen interest in chemistry from a young age. He obtained his Bachelor of Science in Chemistry from the University of Zaragoza and pursued his Ph.D. at the University of Barcelona in the Department of Organic Chemistry. Nebot began his career at the University of Barcelona, where he worked as a postdoctoral researcher. His research focused on developing new drug delivery systems using polymer chemistry. He explored the use of nanoparticles and polymers to improve drug delivery to targeted cells and organs. This research was critical in advancing the field of drug delivery, as it allowed for more effective and targeted drug delivery. In 2008, Nebot joined the University of Valencia as a faculty member in the Department of Polymer Chemistry. He continued his research in drug delivery systems and polymer chemistry, leading a team of researchers in their work. He has been awarded several grants and has published numerous papers in leading scientific journals. Aside from his research, Nebot is known for his mentorship of students and junior researchers. He has trained several Ph.D. students and postdoctoral researchers who have gone on to have successful careers in academia and industry. In recognition of his contributions to the field, Nebot has received several awards, including the Royal Society of Chemistry's Tilden Prize in 2015. He is also a member of several scientific organizations, including the American Chemical Society, the Royal Society of Chemistry, and the European Polymer Federation. Overall, Asensio Nebot's work has significantly contributed to the advancement of drug delivery systems and polymer chemistry. His research has led to new discoveries that have the potential to improve the effectiveness of drugs while minimizing side effects.

Berseba Constituency is situated in the southern region of Namibia. It is one of the eight constituencies in the ǁKaras Region with Berseba town being the capital. The constituency is inhabited by several different groups of people including the Karas, Damara-Nama, Herero, and the San people who were the original inhabitants of the area. The constituency covers an area of 6,166 square kilometers and was established in 1992. It is further subdivided into seven electoral wards, namely Aor ǃNoab, Berseba, //Kharas, Tses, Karasburg East, Karasburg West, and Warmbad. The main economic activity in the area is livestock farming, supplemented by crop cultivation, particularly maize and millet. Berseba constituency is also a hub of traditional crafts and artefacts, with women creating and selling intricate beadwork and jewelry. The town of Berseba is home to a number of small businesses providing services to the surrounding communities. Education is a key priority in Berseba Constituency, with several primary and secondary schools established in the area to ensure that all children have access to quality education. The Namibian government has made significant investments in infrastructure development in the constituency, including roads, healthcare facilities, and water infrastructure. Berseba Constituency has played an important role in the country's history, with many historical sites and landmarks located in the area. The area has long been known as a center of resistance against colonial rule, with many uprisings against the German colonial forces taking place in the early 1900s. The Berseba Mission Station, established in the late 1800s by the Rhenish Mission, serves as a testament to the dedication of the early missionaries in the area. Overall, Berseba Constituency is a vibrant and growing community with a rich history and a promising future. Its people are resilient, hardworking, and dedicated to improving their lives and those of future generations.

NIU College of Visual and Performing Arts (CVPA) is one of the seven colleges at Northern Illinois University located in DeKalb, Illinois. As of fall 2021, the college has approximately 825 undergraduate students and 95 graduate students in six departments. History The college was established in 1956 as the School of Music. In 1971, the School of Music joined the newly established College of Fine Arts, which became the College of Visual and Performing Arts in 2015. Academics The college offers undergraduate and graduate degrees in Art and Design; Music; Theatre and Dance; and the graduate program in Interdisciplinary Arts. The college also offers minors in Arts Leadership and Management, Art History, and Music History. The Art and Design department offers a BFA in Studio Art and a BA in Art History. The Music department offers a BM in Performance, Education, or Composition, as well as a BA in Music. The Theatre and Dance department offers a BA in Theatre and BSs in Theatre Arts and Theatre Education, as well as a BFA in Musical Theatre. The graduate program in Interdisciplinary Arts offers an MFA in Interdisciplinary Arts and a graduate certificate in Community Art. The college is accredited by the National Association of Schools of Art and Design, the National Association of Schools of Music, and the National Association of Schools of Theatre. Facilities The college's facilities include the NIU Art Museum, the Music Building, and the Stevens Building, which houses the School of Theatre and Dance. In addition, the college operates the School of Art and Design's 10,000-square-foot Jack Olson Gallery. Notable alumni CVPA has produced many notable alumni, including actor Richard Jenkins, artist Roland Ginzel, jazz pianist John Campbell, and composer Stacy Garrop.

Amaury Vassili is a French opera singer who was born on June 8th, 1989, in Rouen, France. He is famous for his powerful and versatile vocal range and has become one of the most popular and acclaimed opera singers of his generation. Vassili's musical career began at a young age, as he performed in various local choirs and events in his hometown of Rouen. At the age of 14, he was accepted into the prestigious École Nationale de Musique de Normandie, where he began to cultivate his talents and hone his craft. In 2009, Vassili gained national attention when he was selected to represent France at the Eurovision Song Contest. His operatic performance of the song "Sognu" earned him a spot in the competition's top ten, establishing Vassili as a rising star in the international music scene. Since then, Vassili has released several acclaimed albums and has performed at some of the world's most prestigious venues, including the Olympia Hall in Paris, the Kremlin Palace in Moscow, and the Royal Albert Hall in London. He has also collaborated with a variety of popular artists, including the French pop singer Marc Lavoine and the Italian tenor Vittorio Grigolo. Despite his success in the pop music world, Vassili has remained committed to his roots in classical music, often performing in operas and other productions. His versatility and wide-ranging voice have made him a beloved and respected figure within the world of opera, and he continues to inspire young artists with his artistry and dedication to his craft. Overall, Amaury Vassili is a talented and accomplished opera singer who has earned global acclaim for his powerful voice and expressive performances. His dedication to his craft and his versatility as a performer have set him apart as one of France's most beloved and accomplished musical talents.

The Lee–Hamblin family is a prominent American family known for their contributions to various fields including politics, law, and business. The family traces its roots to Robert E. Lee, who was a prominent general during the American Civil War. The family is also associated with John Hamblin, who was a leading figure during the American Revolutionary War. Julia Lee, a prominent suffragette and activist for women's rights, is also a part of the family. The Lee–Hamblin family is known for their philanthropic activities and has contributed generously to various charitable causes across the country. The family has a rich history spanning several generations, and many members of the family have made significant contributions to American society. For instance, Bruce Lee Hamblin, a descendant of the Lee–Hamblin family, served in the U.S. Army and was awarded the Medal of Honor for his bravery during the Korean War. Another notable member of the family is Frank Hamblin, who was a senior executive at some of the top technology companies in the United States. He is now retired and continues to be involved in various philanthropic activities. The Lee–Hamblin family has also been associated with various political campaigns and has actively contributed to the Republican Party in the United States. Some members of the family have held political office at the state and local level in different parts of the country. Overall, the Lee–Hamblin family is a well-respected and influential family with a rich history and a legacy of contributions to American society. Their dedication to philanthropy, politics, and business has made them an important part of American history and culture.

The Vels were an American new wave band formed in Philadelphia in 1981. The group consisted of brothers Harry and Paul XL and bassist Chas Mastropaolo.[1] The band's early material drew influence from post-punk and new wave bands such as Joy Division, Depeche Mode, and The B-52's. Their debut single, "Private World," was released in 1984 on Mercury Records and received moderate airplay on college radio stations. The band's second single, "Look My Way," was released later that year and was featured in the film The Breakfast Club.[2] In 1985, The Vels released their only full-length album, Velocity, which was produced by Ric Ocasek of The Cars. The album included the single "Girl Most Likely To," which received some radio play but did not chart. Despite positive reviews for the album, The Vels were dropped by Mercury Records shortly after its release. After disbanding, Harry XL went on to work as a producer and engineer, working with artists such as Laurie Anderson and The Sugarcubes. Paul XL and Chas Mastropaolo went on to form the band Chalice, which released two albums in the mid-1990s. The Vels' influence can be heard in the music of later artists such as The Strokes and Interpol, as well as in the indie rock scene of the 2000s.[3] Although The Vels had a brief career, their music continues to be appreciated by fans of 1980s new wave and post-punk. The band's uncompromising attitude towards their music and their willingness to experiment with different genres have made them a cult favorite among fans of the era.

Polyarchy is the term used to describe a political system in which power is held by multiple individuals or groups. This term was first coined by the political scientist Robert Dahl in the 1970s, and it has since become an important concept in the study of comparative politics, particularly in the field of democratic theory. A polyarchy is characterized by a combination of democratic and non-democratic elements. On one hand, there is typically a high degree of political pluralism, meaning that there are multiple political parties, interest groups, and civil society organizations that are active and relatively free to express their views and influence policy decisions. At the same time, however, there may be certain institutional or social barriers that prevent certain groups or individuals from fully participating in the political process, such as discriminatory election laws or deep-seated social prejudices. Despite these limitations, polyarchies are often seen as preferable to other types of political systems, such as authoritarian regimes or one-party states, because they offer at least some measure of political freedom and accountability. Polyarchies can also serve as a useful stepping stone to a more fully-formed democracy, particularly in countries with a history of authoritarianism or instability. Some scholars have raised concerns about the limitations of polyarchies, arguing that they may not go far enough in guaranteeing political freedom and equality for all citizens. Others have suggested that the concept of polyarchy may be too broad and imprecise to provide a clear roadmap for democratic reform. Nonetheless, for many political scientists and advocates of democratic governance, the concept of polyarchy remains a valuable tool for understanding and promoting democratic principles and practices around the world.

Anne Bradstreet (1612-1672) was an English Puritan poet who is considered one of the first female poets to be published in colonial America. She was born in Northamptonshire, England and later moved to Massachusetts Bay Colony with her husband and family in 1630. Bradstreet became well-known for her poetry which often reflected her Puritan beliefs and experiences as a woman in the 17th century. Some of her most well-known works include "To My Dear and Loving Husband," "Upon the Burning of Our House," and "The Prologue." Her poetry often explored themes of love, family, faith, and loss, and is often praised for its sincere and emotional tone. Despite being a woman in a male-dominated Puritan society, Bradstreet's poetry was well-received and respected. It was first published in 1650 in a collection titled "The Tenth Muse Lately Sprung Up in America." The collection was hugely popular and went through several editions in Bradstreet's lifetime. Bradstreet's life was not without hardship, however. She lost her brother, father, and several of her children to illness, and her home and belongings were destroyed in a fire. Despite these tragedies, Bradstreet continued to write poetry and maintain her faith. In addition to her literary accomplishments, Bradstreet is also notable for her contributions to Puritan society. She was a devout and active member of her church community, and her writings often reflect her commitment to her faith. Today, Anne Bradstreet is remembered as a pioneer in American literature and a significant figure in Puritan history. Her poetry continues to be studied and appreciated for its emotional depth and its reflection of colonial life in early America.

Heth Township is one of thirteen townships in Harrison County, Indiana, United States. As of July 1, 2020, Heth Township had a total population of 531 people. Its total area is 5 square miles. Heth Township is located along the Ohio River in Harrison County 8 miles north of Corydon, Indiana. It is bordered by Ewing Township on the east, Adams Township on the southeast, Ohio Township on the south, and Franklin County, Indiana, on the west and north. Perryville, a small census-designated place (CDP), is located in Heth Township. The area was named by former settler William Heth, who came from Kentucky. It is said that he was an adventurous man with a good sense of humor and he traveled the Ohio Valley looking for adventure. The first known pioneer in the area was Edward Howell, who settled in Heth Township in 1809. For many years, Heth Township was known for its thriving tobacco industry. During the Civil War, Heth Township was one of the first portions of Harrison County to join the cause of the Union. Heth Township is served by the North Harrison Community School Corporation. Perryville is in a separate school district, the South Harrison Community School Corporation. Heth Township has several small businesses and many small farms. It is part of a larger farming region in Harrison County, which is known for its vineyards, wineries, and small-scale agricultural production. Heth Township is served by a volunteer fire department called "Heth-Perry Fire & Rescue". The fire department provides fire protection services to the towns and communities of Heth Township and Perryville, as well as providing mutual aid to other fire departments in Harrison County. Heth Township is an unincorporated community, with much of the township still being rural farmland and wooded areas. Motorists traveling along the Ohio River can easily access the adjacent communities of Ewing, Indiana and Corydon, Indiana from Heth Township. There is also a small private airstrip located in Heth Township, called Robertson Airpark. It is mainly used for private aircraft and small planes, but also is utilized by recreational use such as skydiving. Heth Township is located within Harrison County, making it a great place to experience some of the local culture and scenery. The nearby Kunkel's Mill Covered Bridge is located within Heth Township and is a historic landmark. The area is popular with outdoorsmen and nature enthusiasts who visit the nearby Harrison-Crawford State Forest, located 15 miles south of Heth Township. Heth Township is a unique and beautiful area in Harrison County, Indiana. It is a combination of rural farmland, wooded areas, and small towns, all with their own history and culture.

Prosopometamorphopsia is a rare and rarefied condition characterized by the individual's visual perception of other people's faces transforming into the faces of familiar figures, often beloved family members, friends and even animals. The condition has been termed "Metamorphopsia of the Human Face" and is often associated with temporal lobe epilepsy. It was first acknowledged by neurologist and psychiatrist Auguste Bouisson in 1878. People affected by prosopometamorphopsia often first notice the faces of loved ones, such as parents, siblings or children, morphing into the faces of different individuals as they look away from the person and back again. In some cases, the face will change instantaneously, or even switch back and forth between two or more individuals, such as a parent and a pet. In other cases, the transformation occurs slowly and with notable changes in the features seen in the face. The condition is not associated with visual hallucinations, as those affected by prosopometamorphopsia can clearly distinguish between the shifting faces and the actual person in question. It is more likely an issue with visual processing in the brain, as people with temporal lobe epilepsy often experience this issue. This is due to the way in which images and faces are processed, stored and retrieved in the brain, resulting in the misperception that someone's face has changed when it has not. Though prosopometamorphopsia is comparatively rare, it can have a serious impact on social situations. Those affected may become apprehensive of unfamiliar people or environments, as they fear seeing their faces transform. This fear can make socializing, attending social events and going outside difficult for those with the condition. Fortunately, medical professionals are beginning to address this condition. Various treatments are available, including medications, cognitive behavioral therapy and, where necessary, physical therapy. In addition, patients may benefit from support from family and friends, as well as group sessions with individuals who are also affected. Though prosopometamorphopsia remains relatively unknown, it is an increasingly recognised condition. As medical professionals become aware of the symptoms and impact it can have, those affected by it can receive the medical and emotional help they need to manage their condition.

The Lithuanian Supercup is a one-off match in Lithuanian football held at the beginning of the domestic season. The match is contested by the previous season's A lyga and Lithuanian Football Cup winners. There are no promotions or relegations and the trophy is awarded to the winner of the match. The first edition of the Lithuanian Supercup was held in 1994, when FK Žalgiris won the match against FK Vaidotas; the match finished 2–0. FK Žalgiris have by far been the most successful team in the competition, having emerged victorious in 8 of the 24 editions of the Supercup to date. Atlantas Klaipėda hold the record of being the second most successful team, as they have won the match on four occasions. The 24th edition of the Lithuanian Supercup was held on 16 July 2017 in the Lithuania Megal, with FK Trakai victorious over FK Žalgiris with a 3–2 score in extra-time. Mindaugas Žužas scored all of FK Trakai's three goals in the match, which made him the top scorer of the Supercup till now. The most unifying feature of the 24 editions of the Lithuanian Supercup has been the attendance. Substantial crowds, averaging around 10,000, have come from all over the country to watch the match and cheer on the two teams. In fact, the largest crowd ever found in a Lithuanian Supercup match was in 2010 when nearly 20,000 people attended the match at the LFF Stadium in Vilnius. In recent years, the Lithuanian Supercup has become an event for entertainment and marketing for Lithuanian businesses. Many businesses have sponsored the match in order to promote their companies and boost sales. Additionally, the match has become a medium for promoting various sports clubs and teams, with many clubs using the match to announce their new signings and players. Thus, the Lithuanian Supercup has evolved into a much more than just a match between two teams aiming to win the trophy. It is now a major event in Lithuanian football and a platform for various businesses and teams to culminate their efforts to promote football in the country.

The 1888 Open Championship was the 28th Open Championship, held 14–15 June at Prestwick Golf Club in Prestwick, South of Scotland. The Championship was won by Jack Burns, who scored 167 to win the tournament by three shots over runner-up Willie Campbell. The event was the final Open Championship to be played over 36 holes, switching to 72 holes the following year. This tournament marks the first instance in any major tournament of two professional golfers playing as partners. The pairing of Willie Park Sr. and Mungo Park was a successful one, as they finished in third place with a score of 172. With an additional professional partner, John Ball, the team shot a far more respectable score of 168 for the two rounds. A total of 48 players entered the Championship, and the winner received a prize of £10. The competition was divided into two divisions with the top sixteen players (selected according to their listed handicaps) competing in the first division and the remaining players competing in the second division. The course at Prestwick, a classic Scottish links course, was notorious for being a demanding test of golf. In the first round of play, the winds were gusty and combined with the deceptively difficult greens, which Jack Burns described as “lightning fast” to putt on, the course proved to be a stern test. Burns and Campbell, who started the final round tied, broke away from the field with a score of 82 and 79, respectively, in the second round, with Burns shooting a consistent round of 81, 83 to take the title. The Scottish dominance of the Open Championship as well as golf in general was clear with the top four finishers all being Scottish. This dominance was due in part to the small field size as compared to other events and the fact that the event was not well known outside of Scotland at this time. This was Jack Burns’ second and final victory in the Championship, having previously won in 1880. He is one of only two players to win the Championship twice, the other being Willie Park Sr.. The 1888 Open Championship was the final Open Championship to be held at Prestwick prior to the introduction of the Open Championship’s rota system in 1895.

Shruti (from Sanskrit श्रुति, meaning "tone, sound") is a concept in Indian classical music, referring to the smallest semitone of the raga or melody. It is an essential part of the musical system of India and is the basis for all melody and harmony in Indian music. Shruti refers to the microtones between melodic notes, which are notated using quarter-tone notation. In order to perform a given raga, musicians must be very well-versed in the structure and technique of using these microtones, which require a greater degree of accuracy than regular semitones. Indian instruments such as the sitar, tabla and veena are tuned to particular shrutis, which are very particular frequencies. Some Indian systems have 12 shrutis, based on the 12-semitone division of the octave. There are two categories of shrutis, Shuddha and Vikrut, or "natural" and "altered." Shuddha shrutis are the pitches of the seven basic swaras of the Octave, while Vikrut shrutis are more finely tuned microtones that occur between the basic swaras. In Indian music, musicians use the shrutis to create a feeling of movement in the music, as well as to set a mood or create an atmosphere. In addition, the differences between various shrutis can be used to create a certain kind of tension. This is why they are so important to Indian classical music and why they play such a large role in Indian musical tradition. In recent years, shrutis have been used in western music as well, combining different musical genres. However, this is still a relatively novel concept and its usage is still in its early stages. Shruti is an ancient concept and it has been around for centuries. It is a fundamental part of Indian music, and it is important for musicians to understand and master the art of using shrutis in order to perform a given raga or melody in the most authentic way. This is why shrutis are so important to Indian music and have continued to be so for so long.

Dennington is a small village and civil parish situated in the Waveney Valley, in the county of Suffolk, England. The village has a population of about 640. It is located about 13 miles (21 km) south of Norwich. The village can be traced back to at least 1050 A.D. and the Domesday Book of 1086, in which it is recorded as Denitone and belonging to William d'Ecouis. Dennington was changed to Deninctune by the 13th century. The village is nestled between two hills, known as the "Dennington Hills" and is known to be one of the most picturesque villages in the area. The church of St Mary, the oldest building in the village, dates back to the 12th century. It is a grade one listed building with a Norman font, 15th century oak screen and a remarkable stained glass window by Edward Burne-Jones. The village has a pub, a post office, a village hall, a primary school and a veterinary surgery. The former Dennington Railway, which was opened in 1887 was closed in 1966. The disused railway line serves as a path for walkers and cyclists and has provided an important ‘green corridor’ for wildlife. The village is home to the Dennington Wildlife and Bird Trust, a nature reserve which spans across two sites owned and managed by the Trust. The reserve consists of coppiced woodland, species-rich grassland, an old quarry and a lake. A wide variety of wildlife and plants can be found at the reserve, including dormice and otters. The village holds an annual flower show and the Dennington Village Society is active in promoting the interests of the local community. There are also regular talks, events and activities by various supports groups, such as Dennington Footpaths and Dennington Youth Group. The neighbouring village of Peasenhall is home to the Peasenhall Peasant, a scarecrow festival, also known as "The Big Scarecrow Weekend", which is held every year in May. In 2018, the village was chosen to be featured in the BBC half-hour documentary series Village of Dreams. The documentary followed local couples, who have been part of the community for generations, and showcased the lives and traditions of the village. The village is served by a regular bus service to nearby towns, with further rail and road links connecting it to Norwich and Ipswich. Overall, Dennington is a beautiful and peaceful village, combining traditional rural life with modern amenities and is home to a friendly and welcoming community.

Szkieve (pronounced: sk - ee - vuh) is a furry sci-fi/fantasy artist, illustrator and writer. They are best known for their webcomic, Path of the Dragon, and their cover art for books such as the Horned Rat series by Neal Asher. Szkieve was born in Poland and grew up living in Croatia, with regular visits to the United States. They are currently residing in Portland, Oregon. Szkieve has been creating art since the age of five and cites the influence of Disney movies and animated shows from their childhood as the starting point for their work. Szkieve initially found success in the online art community by promoting their artwork through auctions, commissions, and drawings placed in print media. This led to an invitation in 2014 to attend the AnthroCon convention in California as a special guest. Since then, they have become a regular speaker and panelist at conventions throughout the USA, Europe and Asia. In 2015, Szkieve started the webcomic "Path of the Dragon", in which they explore high fantasy with anthropomorphic characters. It quickly gained a large following and was featured in the anthology "Anthrobunny". In addition to their original work, Szkieve's illustration portfolio includes cover art for novels such as the Horned Rat series by Neal Asher, "The Witch of Erfurt" by Vincent Capri and the "Sorceress's Phantom" by V.S. Dots. They have also collaborated with book publishers such as HarperCollins and Del Rey for book jacket illustrations. Aside from illustration and comics, Szkieve has also collaborated on various video game projects, such as the game "Earth Call" by Vulpine Games. In 2018, Szkieve launched the game "Ouroboros", a turn-based strategy game for which they served as Art Director. Throughout their career, Szkieve has garnered numerous awards, including "Best Anthropomorphic Cover Artist" from Ireland's Mostly Furry Things (2017) and the Silver Marker Award from Attic Reign (2020). In 2020, Szkieve was also included as part of the Out of the Ashes: Artists in the Making exhibition at the Portland Art Museum, featuring a particularly dynamic piece comprised of an illustration and a soundscape. Szkieve is an artist who has dedicated themselves to the world of furry illustration, cover art, comics and beyond. Their light-hearted, bold art has brought joy to their supporters who have watched them grow and develop their craft over the years.

Joe Grey is an American entrepreneur, investor, engineer and philanthropist. He is most widely known for founding and leading Gray Wolf Exploration LLC, an energy exploration and development company. Joe Grey was born in Houston, Texas on June 15, 1980. He began studying engineering at the University of Texas at Austin, but soon transferred to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) where he earned his bachelor's degree in Mechanical Engineering. After earning his degree, Grey worked as a research and development engineer at Schlumberger, a major oil services and technology firm. In 2007, Grey founded Gray Wolf Exploration. Under his leadership, the company became a leader in deposits exploration and exploitation. The company soon acquired a number of strategic assets, including a significant stake in the natural gas reserves of the Gulf of Mexico and onshore shale projects, leading to significant growth in the firm's operations. In less than a decade, Grey had built Gray Wolf Exploration into a major player in the energy industry, eventually merging the company with another oil and gas firm and selling it to Chevron for a reported sum of more than $225 million in 2017. Following the sale of Gray Wolf Exploration, Grey retired from active business and invested his money in philanthropic projects. Since then, he has devoted much of his time and resources to various charitable causes. He is considered an effective, generous philanthropist with a focus on improving education and alleviating poverty. Grey has also recently become involved in environmental causes, investing in sustainable energy initiatives and developing strategies to reduce carbon emissions. Apart from philanthropy, Joe Grey also writes books on entrepreneurship and investing and lectures at universities around the world. Having started his own business from almost nothing and grown it into a major success story, he is regarded as a highly sought-after mentor and advisor in the world of venture capital. Overall, Joe Grey is a successful entrepreneur, investor and philanthropist with a reputation as a quietly effective and generous contributor to charitable causes. His success, determination and ever increasing influence in the worlds of venture capital and philanthropy have earned him the admiration of many and he is quickly becoming a symbol of success and a model of leadership and philanthropy in the world of business.

Hebert High School is a public high school located in the city of Borger, Texas. It is part of the Borger Independent School District and serves 9-12 graders. The school's mascot is the Hebert Hawk and the colors are purple and gold. The school was established in the fall of 1971 and is named for the late educator W.D. Hebert. Hebert High School is proud of its academic and extracurricular achievements. The school is proud of its academic programs, including AP and IB courses, and its extracurricular activities, such as marching band, student council, and competitive sports. The extracurricular program also includes a variety of clubs and organizations such as National Honor Society and Spanish Club, as well as its own student-run newspaper, The Hawk. Hebert High School offers a variety of clubs and organizations such as Friends of the Arts, National Honor Society, National Technical Honor Society, StuCo, Design and Drawing, Spanish Club, Student Council, Ski Club, Anime Club and much more. In addition, the school has a rich tradition of athletic programs, hosting teams in football, basketball, swimming, soccer, baseball, softball, golf, track and field, volleyball, wrestling, and cross country. The athletic teams have enjoyed great success over the years, with the Hebert Hawks Football Team winning the 4A UIL State Football Championship in 2004. Hebert High School has strived to create an atmosphere of excellence and achievement. The principal, Mr. Paul Ruiz, is a strong advocate for providing a nurturing and safe learning environment for all Hebert Students. A variety of programs are available to support and encourage student learning, including the Hebert Honors Program, an internationally recognized education program that focuses on student achievement. Hebert High School offers a well-rounded educational experience and an extensive array of opportunities to learn and grow. The school provides students with a positive and supportive environment that encourages success both inside and outside the classroom. Hebert High School is a great place for students to discover their talents and reach their goals.

African Sources for African History is an academic field devoted to the study and use of historical records from within Africa to research and study African history. The field has developed significantly and grown in importance in the past few decades, due to an increased focus on African scholarship and the recognition of African history as a legitimate area of study. African Sources for African History encompasses a wide range of historical records, such as oral traditions, written texts, archaeological artifacts, monuments, and even visual records, such as paintings and photographs. It is essential that historians in the field recognize the different nature of each type of evidence, as the manner in which evidence is interpreted and understood can vary between different types. Oral traditions, passed down through generations, are an important source of African history. These traditions often provide insight into pre-colonial Africa, before the development of westernized written records. Historians are aware, however, that over time, these oral traditions can become muddled and misinterpreted; due to this, utilizing oral traditions as an authoritative source of evidence is often met with criticism. In terms of written records, archival research of both European and African sources has played a significant role in the study of African history. Colonial archives, such as those from the British, Portuguese, French and Dutch empires, often provide evidence on events that occurred during the colonial period, but may present a Euro-centric or skewed perspective. African archival sources, such as local newspapers, church records, and published accounts from Africans, are also an important part of the research. In some cases, even correspondence between local rulers is useful. Additionally, African historians in the field can also use memoirs, contemporaneous travelers’ accounts, oral accounts, and even court records as evidence. Archaeological records, such as tools, tools, jewelry, and pottery, provide evidence of the daily life and culture of pre-colonial Africa. Furthermore, monuments and architectural remains, such as ancient burial grounds, ruins of settlements and stone sculptures, are often studied to gain insight into the past. Visual records, such as photographs, paintings, and sketches, also provide evidence about African history and culture. Such records can often provide a glimpse into the past and show the many cultures that have existed in Africa over time. In conclusion, African Sources for African History is an important area of research and study, providing various records that shed light on Africa’s past, present, and future. As historians in the field gain more experience and expertise in deciphering different historical sources, the accuracy and qualitative nature of research pertaining to African history will likely only improve.

2012–13 Stoke City F.C. season is the 114th season of the English club Stoke City F.C. and their sixth season competing in the Premier League,the top flight of English football. It is their fifth consecutive season in the top flight of English football, since their promotion from the Football League Championship in the 2008/2009 season. The season began on 18 August 2012 with a 3–1 home win against Reading, and concluded on 19 May 2013, with Stoke losing 5–1 away at Southampton. The season saw Stoke finish in 13th place with 45 points. They reached the final 16 stage of the 2012-13 League Cup, saw Joe Allen make his debut for the club in a 2–2 draw against Arsenal and also saw the arrival of American defender Geoff Cameron as a new player addition to the beginning of the season. Stoke were eliminated from the FA Cup at the first knock-out stage, when they were beaten 3–1 at Anfield by Premier League leaders Liverpool. In December, Tony Pulis left the club by mutual consent, ending a near-eight-year tenure at Stoke City. He was replaced by Mark Hughes, who was appointed on a 3-year contract. In his last match, Stoke claimed a 4–0 win at home to Wigan Athletic – a scoreline that marked Hughes’ first match in charge. Player and staff overhauls saw the arrivals of Charlie Adam, Michael Kightly, Jack Butland, Jamie Ness, Marc Muniesa and Erik Pieters, whilst the season saw the departures of Michael Owen, Matthew Upson, Dean Whitehead, Rory Delap, Dave Kitson, Tuncay Şanlı, Wilson Palacios and Carlo Nash. Despite a difficult start, the season ended well under Hughes, with Stoke defeating Liverpool, Manchester United and Arsenal away from home, and lifting the club to a finish of 13th place in the Premier League. The club also announced a record turn-over of £78 million and the highest-ever position in the club's history - 46th in the Deloitte Football Money League. Overall, the 2012-13 was a successful season for Stoke, despite some mid-season turbulence. They finished the season strongly and even managed to secure a top-profit of £1.8m in the 2012/13 season. This was the first time in five years that Stoke City held a top profit rather than a loss in a Premier League season.

Used to Love is a song by Dutch DJ and producer Martin Garrix and Australian singer-songwriter Dean Lewis. Released on November 30, 2019, the track is the fourth single from Garrix's upcoming fourth studio album. The track starts out with Dean Lewis' soulful and melancholic vocals, followed by a lush and dance-like production by Martin Garrix. The two artists blend electronic and acoustic elements, which result in an emotion-charged song. The track is a melancholy yet upbeat electronica, exploring themes of emotional pain and break-up. Lewis shares his emotional trauma through his angelic vocals and speaks of a relationship that had gone wrong. Garrix accentuates and emphasizes the lyrics of Lewis' verses with a catchy chorus and a powerful blend of EDM and rock influences. The song has an inspirational tone of resilience, recognizing that breakups are uncomfortable but you must be strong, because life will continue to move on. The single was released for streaming and digital purchases on November 30, 2019. The accompanying music video was premiered on Martin Garrix's official YouTube channel on December 7, 2019. It was directed by Emil Nava and takes an experimental route with a unique narrative. The video follows the duo in an action-packed car chase, showcasing close-up shots of Garrix as he is racing on the highway. It received acclaim from music video critics and was described as a “distinct visual experience” by Billboard. The track performed well on the music charts, reaching number one in the UK Dance Chart and number three on the US Dance/Mix Show Airplay chart. It also peaked at number nine on the UK Singles Chart and number twenty-four in Australia. The single was also Grammy-nominated in the 2021 lineup, where it was in the running for "Best Dance Recording". Garrix and Lewis were two artists whose styles had already been well known before their collaboration, so Used to Love served as a reminder of their potential to make an inspiring and successful single together. The track is well-received by fans and critics alike and continues to be a fan favorite.

Yabba Dabba Doo! is an iconic catchphrase which originated in the American animated television series The Flintstones, the first major primetime animated series on television. It is typically used as a celebration of good times and was most famously uttered by the show’s main protagonist Fred Flintstone when excited. In addition to its use in The Flintstones, the phrase has become a popular cultural reference, with multiple uses in popular media and merchandise. The Flintstones aired for six seasons on ABC from 1960 to 1966, and was created by Hanna-Barbera Productions. Released in the same era as The Simpsons, it is believed to have greatly contributed to the success of primetime animation in the United States. The Flintstones centered around the Stone Age adventures of the titular family, who lived in the fictional town of Bedrock. and were comprised of Fred Flintstone, the breadwinner and husband, Wilma Flintstone, his wife, Pebbles Flintstone, their young daughter and Dino, their pet dinosaur. The catchphrase “Yabba Dabba Doo!” was introduced into the show in 1962 by Fred’s character as a way to express joy and excitement, and was said in reaction to moments like a successful golf swing or a beneficial spin in a game of chance. As the series progressed, the phrase began to take on a life of its own, appearing in promotional materials and other pieces of media outside of the show, such as statues and buttons. In addition to becoming a cultural icon in its own right, the saying has made appearances in various movies and television programs over the years. It was most recently used in an episode of the TV show Futurama, as well as an episode of The Simpsons. It has also been featured in songs and video games, such as in an update to the classic game Worms in which a character exclaims “Yabba Dabba Doo!” after victory. As well as its appearance in pop culture, the phrase has also been used to name various clothing brands, toys and other products. In 2010, a popular online clothing store, Yabba Dabba Doo!, was opened in the United Kingdom, and has since expanded to several countries over the years. The phrase has also been used in advertising campaigns and as the name of a beer brand produced by the American brewing company, Anheuser-Busch. In conclusion, “Yabba Dabba Doo!” has become an iconic phrase which has been embraced by the general public as a lighthearted way to show enthusiasm or happiness. Despite its humble origins in the 1960’s, the phrase has been adopted by modern cultures and is now used in various pieces of media, products, and advertisements.

Sandy Vee is a French DJ, songwriter and producer. A pioneer in the House music genre, Vee was a major influence on the global House music movement in the 2000s and 2010s. Sandy's first DJ residency was in Belgium in the late 1990s, quickly becoming a well known figure on the local and international House music scene. Throughout his career Sandy has had many different releases including his EPs 'Hide & Seek' and 'Without You'. These EPs showcased Sandy's signature house music style, an uplifting and feel-good sound with an emphasis on melody. His releases have been supported by some of the biggest names in the industry such as Armin van Buuren and Tiësto. Sandy is also responsible for remixing some of the biggest names in House, such as Steve Angello, Axwell and Eric Prydz. The sounds he creates have opened his music up to a much wider audience and gained him recognition from fans around the world. In addition to releases and DJ sets, Sandy has established his own label House For The People, which has seen him work with some of the top names in the industry as well as launching several successful singles. Sandy also regularly produces his own radio show, The V.I.P. Sessions, which connects music fans from around the world and has featured artists like Kölsch and Maceo Plex. Sandy Vee is considered to be one of France's best known and internationally respected House music producers. He has been instrumental in the success of EDM and club culture, always looking for new ways to push boundaries and help the genre evolve. He continues to inspire music fans around the world with his classic house sound and has established himself as a key figure in the industry.

Frank Archer (1837-1917) was an English politician. Born and raised in Manchester, he began his political career in local government, serving as a Councillor for Ardwick from 1887-1901. In 1901, he was elected to the House of Commons as a Conservative Member of Parliament for Manchester Rusholme, serving until 1906. Archer was a strong advocate for the economy and fiscal policy during his time as an MP, making important contributions to the Tariff Reform debate. He argued for a duty-free empire, land-tax reform and proposed a tax on luxuries in order to be able to reduce the burden of taxation upon the working classes. He was also a promoter of labour exchanges, which were aimed at managing the rising unemployment levels at the time. In addition to his work in the House of Commons, Archer was a strong supporter of the Temperance Movement and worked with others to promote it. He also campaigned actively for the issue of Women's Suffrage and was a member of the National Political Union, which fought for suffrage. Archer was a noted philanthropist and involved himself in many charitable organisations. He was President of the Manchester Philosophical Society and a member of the Manchester Medical and Manchester Royal Exchange Literary Societies. In addition to this, he was an active Freemason and held several offices. After his time in Parliament ended, Archer returned to local politics and served on various councils for local charities. He is remembered for his lifelong commitment to social reform and as an advocate of fiscal policy reform. During his retirement he wrote several books, starting his memoirs in 1906. Throughout his life, Archer was a respected figure in the political and social circles of Manchester. Upon his death in 1917, he was widely mourned, with a memorial being held in his honour at Ardwick Town Hall. Frank Archer serves as an example of the ideal of public service, dedicating his life to improving the lives of others.

Young Dan'l Boone was an American pioneer, hunter, and explorer who lived during the 18th century. He was the sixth of eleven children born to Squire Boone, III and Sarah Morgan Boone in the valley of Oley, Pennsylvania in 1734. As a youth, young Dan'l, as he was usually called, was a curious and eager learner. He showed an eagerness to explore the wilderness and to study the plants and animals he encountered. His parents took him and his siblings on hunting trips in search of game where he learned to use a rifle, to trap and to track wildlife. At the age of 15, young Dan’l moved with his family to the Yadkin River in what is now North Carolina. He enjoyed hunting and exploring the new land, but did not stay long. In 1750, the Boone family moved west to what is now Kentucky. Here, Dan’l was captivated by the wilderness, its beauty and its possibilities. His love of the wilderness, his courage and adventurous spirit made him a legendary figure in the American frontier. In 1767, after battling Native Americans, Dan’l attempted to settle on what is now the Kentucky River. He was unsuccessful, however, and in 1770, he led a group of settlers to the area that is now Boone County, Kentucky. He eventually became the first permanent European settler in the area. He built a fort he named Boonesborough, which soon became a refuge for many people fleeing Native American raids. For the remainder of his life, Dan’l explored, hunted, traded and fought off Native Americans as he traveled through the American frontier. He earned the respect of many of the pioneers who followed him and was a much revered figure in his day for his courage and resourcefulness. Young Dan'l Boone was one of the greatest American pioneers of the 18th century. He helped to open up the country to Western expansion and was one of the first to explore and settle Kentucky. His contributions to American life are remembered to this day and he will be remembered as an important part of the nation's history.

Judgment Day (2005) is a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). It took place on May 22, 2005, at the HP Pavilion in San Jose, California. It was the seventh annual Judgement Day event. The main event featured John Cena defending the WWE Championship against JBL. Cena beat JBL to retain the WWE Championship after pinning him following an FU. The undercard featured five matches, including a no-contest between Eddie Guerrero and Rey Mysterio for the WWE United States Championship and an interpromotional match between Kurt Angle and Shawn Michaels. The event featured eight professional wrestling matches, each involving different wrestlers from pre-existing scripted rivalries and storylines. Wrestlers portrayed either heroes, villains, or reliant characters in the scripted events that built tension and culminated into a wrestling match. The first match of the show pitted Eddie Guerrero against Rey Mysterio for the WWE United States Championship. Midway through the match, both competitors were disqualified for using objects as weapons. The second match featured Booker T, Chris Benoit and Shawn Michaels in a Triple Threat match. Booker T pinned Benoit after a Scissors Kick to win the match. The third match saw Kurt Angle challenge Shawn Michaels in a "Battle of the Brands" Interpromotional Match. Angle won the match after pinning Michaels following an Angle Slam. The fourth match featured The Big Show against Muhammad Hassan in a Singles Match. Big Show won the match via pinfall by delivering a Chokeslam to Hassan. The fifth match pitted Phoenix and Melina in a Divas Tag Team Match. Phoenix and Melina won the match when Phoenix made Melina tap out to the Sharpshooter. The sixth match saw Charlie Haas challenging Chris Jericho for the WWE Intercontinental Championship. Jericho won the match after pinning Haas following a Codebreaker. The seventh match saw Edge and Randy Orton in a singles match for the World Heavyweight Championship. Edge won the match and the World Heavyweight Championship when he pinned Orton following a Spear. The main event saw John Cena defend the WWE Championship against JBL. Cena won the match, and retained the WWE Championship, after pinning JBL following an FU. Judgment Day (2005) was, in terms of buys, the lowest-selling Judgement Day event of all time. Critics have generally given negative reviews for the event, citing it as lackluster and uninteresting.

Old wave is a term coined in the late 2000s to describe the cultural wave of older music genres, specifically rock and metal. Many up-and-coming acts were attempting to recapture the sound of the old wave in a modern context. It is not to be confused with classic rock, which refers to a particular period in Rock and Roll which started in roughly the mid 60s and ended in roughly the early 80s. The revival of old wave genres started around 2005 when acts such as Steel Panther, Jet, Taking Back Sunday, The Darkness, and Franz Ferdinand began to gain popularity. These acts all had a tendency to take the classic, classic rock sound and lyrics and put them into a modern context by altering their instrumentation and production to fit the times. The new wave brought in a new audience who, after being saturated with processional pop music from the mid 90s onwards, sought to recover the musical "edge" that rock and metal had once possessed. Old wave has come to encompass a number of genres, including classic rock, hard rock, blues-rock, and metalcore. It can be heard in the sound of greats such as AC/DC or Led Zeppelin, but also in the sound of more modern bands like Halestorm or Disturbed. Generally, it is characterized as having an intense, rock-inspired sound, with particular attention being paid to guitar tones, song structures, and vocal delivery. Old wave has had a resurgence in the last decade, and its influence can be seen in the styles of younger bands such as The Pretty Reckless, Halestorm, and Ghost. Due to its blend of classic rock and metal influences, the genre appealed to a wider audience who were looking for something familiar, yet modern. Additionally, many of the acts that were developing in the scene have since gone on to great success, making old wave a viable style in popular music. Though old wave has made a big comeback in recent years, it is still considered to be on the fringe of mainstream music, and for the most part stays confined to specialty radio programs and independent media outlets. Its deep grooves, its blues-based guitar riffs, and its classic metal sound continue to inspire young bands, and will likely be heard for many years to come.

Lois Griffin (born August 5, 1957) is an American Politician who served as mayor of Quahog, Rhode Island until the 2006 election. Born in Quahog, She is the daughter of Robert and Barbara Pewterschmidt and the wife of Peter Griffin. She graduated from Quahog High School in 1975 and attended Brown University where she earned a double major in Political Science and Women's Studies. After returning to Quahog, she held a variety of jobs including waitressing in a restaurant, as a flight attendant, and working at the Quahog ferry. In 2000, she ran for mayor of Quahog, challenging incumbent Mayor Adam West. After two bruising campaigns, she won the election and was sworn in on January 2, 2001. During her tenure, Lois successfully brought infrastructure improvements to Quahog such as a new city hall, a new library, and renovations to the Quahog Museum. She also successfully lobbied for a new port authority and the Quahog Arts Council. However, her biggest success was her stewardship of the Quahog economy. During her tenure, Lois helped to bring additional revenue to Quahog in the form of a property tax rebate for homeowners.
